content.content: MIP55c3-SP10: Pioneer a DeFi-Native Dataset for Modelling Sentiment-driven Dynamics and Risks SPF  Preamble MIP55c3-SP10: Pioneer a DeFi-Native Dataset for Modelling Sentiment-driven Dynamics and Risks Author(s): @pvl Contributors: Tags: spf Status: Withdrawn Date Proposed: 2022-09-16 Date Ratified: Amount Requested: 50k DAI Recipient Address: 0x6ebB1A9031177208A4CA50164206BF2Fa5ff7416 Forum URL: https://forum.makerdao.com/t/mip55c3-sp10-pioneer-a-defi-native-dataset-for-modelling-sentiment-driven-dynamics-and-risks/17942 Ratification Poll URL: Extra: This subproposal was withdrawn by its author and replaced by [MIP55c3-SP11](https://forum.makerdao.com/t/mip55c3-sp11-pioneer-defi-focused-language-dataset-for-the-benefit-of-risk-modelling-govcomms/18802).   Sentence Summary This SPF will fund the creation of the first DeFi-focused dataset to train models detecting DeFi community sentiment/narratives. It will be used to augment and extend the Risk CU’s (RISK-001’s) modelling to discover and predict currently hidden risks.  Paragraph Summary The Risk CU’s modelling currently covers only part of market risks. Maker needs to augment the EMH-based risk model in use with a model of market sentiment and narratives and its mutual bidirectional interaction with on-chain activity. This SPF will fund the creation of the first DeFi-focused dataset for training sentiment/narrative detection models. It’s part of the web3-native intelligence program.  Motivation This SPF will fund creation of the first DeFi-focused dataset for training sentiment/narrative detection models that will be used to augment and extend the Risk CU’s modelling with products like:  An early warning system for events like Black Thursday: be aware in advance => get prepared, the UST case. Simulations and stress-testing: Chaos Labs are building a simulation environment to run Maker’s software against agents and scenarios. Currently they’re built around a set of theoretical premises. Models of crypto community sentiment/narratives learned from real-life data could be used to build true to life agents and scenaries. Products from pp 1, 2 could be wrapped into products for other web3 stakeholders: DAOs, users, investors. Could be serious competition for Gauntlet’s business, which is suboptimal for web3. If open sourced, datasets and models could also be a valuable public good, from which the whole web3 community could benefit => PR/reputation benefit for Maker.  The Risk CU’s modelling currently covers only part of market risks. Maker needs to augment the EMH-based risk model in use with a model of market sentiment and narratives and its mutual bidirectional interaction with on-chain activity.  The key assumption at the heart of the Risk CU’s model is the Efficient-market hypothesis (EMH). It implies that an asset price is objectively determined by the entirety of available information about the asset and its value (in the form of present discounted value). The market is rational and each price movement is the reflection of the new information unpredictably emerging. Hence we’re modelling it as a random process with Monte Carlo simulations. However, Nobel-winning research by Robert Shiller shows that irrational factors like sentiment and narratives play an equally important role in asset pricing. In fact, the Nobel Prize in Economics '13 was shared by Shiller and Eugene Fama, the creator of the Efficient-market hypothesis. This underscores that EHM- and sentiment/narrative-driven asset pricing are two complimentary mechanisms and market risk modelling should be handled accordingly. The most obvious example of irrational exuberance on financial markets are bubbles like the one happened around UST — all information about its model was open, yet the bubble emerged and then collapsed. Wild price volatility not explainable by objective economic factors, including crypto winters, happening to more mature assets like ETH is also an example of risks not covered by risk models based on the Efficient-market hypothesis.  This project is a continuation of the work on web3-native intelligence. At the previous step I showed that the UST stablecoin crash in May could be predicted by significant downward movement in sentiment towards UST starting in mid-April resulting in the loss of confidence => panic => death spiral. Now the goal is to improve model’s accuracy by creating the first DeFi-focused dataset to train language models for analysis of the DeFi community sentiment.  Special Purpose Fund Name Pioneer a DeFi-Native Dataset for Modelling Sentiment-driven Dynamics and Risks  Special Purpose Fund Scope & Work Credentials This SPF will fund the next step of the web3-native intelligence program as follows:  Assemble the first DeFi-focused corpus of English tweets for language model pre-training. Pretrain BERTweet_large on the DeFi corpus from step 1. Build a software pipeline necessary for dynamic adversarial data collection (DADC). Run around 20 (depending on intermediate results) small DADC rounds.   Funding Breakdown Fund the steps from the previous paragraph as follows:  5k DAI 5k DAI 8k DAI : 4.1 8k DAI after DADC round 5; 4.2 8k DAI after DADC round 10; 4.3 8k DAI after DADC round 15; 4.4 8k DAI after the last DADC round.   Special Purpose Fund Details Official Contact or Group Name: pvl Contact Email/Handle: @pvl Date Added: 2022-09-16 Total Amount: 50k DAI Wallet Address: 0x6ebB1A9031177208A4CA50164206BF2Fa5ff7416 Comptroller signers: @Patrick_J, TBD

content.content: The fact is that Risk CU & Chaos Labs don’t even have tools to cover sentiment/narrative-driven risks. Risk CU is concentrating on the EMH part of market risks. Chaos Labs don’t even touch risk models. To gauge sentiment you need to train language models. And for that you need datasets. Risk CU & Chaos Labs don’t have such datasets, in fact nobody in DeFi has them. This SPF funds creating such dataset. Risk CU and Chaos Labs also don’t work with language models. In other words Risk CU couldn’t cover non-EMH market risks, even if they wanted. This SPF solves this problem. And Chaos Labs’ mandate is totally different from modelling risks. As for the significance of sentiment/narrative-driven market risks.  Screenshot 2022-09-17 at 15.20.231438×1078 159 KB  A detrended version.  Screenshot 2022-09-17 at 15.49.291600×1226 164 KB  These graphs show the deviation of the actual asset prices from those that could be modeled by EMH-based risk models as the one employed by Risk CU (the perfect foresight price). To me it looks very significant. And there is no reason to assume that crypto market is less irrationally volatile and more efficient than stock markets. Most likely on the contrary given the role social media and social networks play in initiating and reinforcing trends in web3/DeFi. These risks remain uncovered at present.

content.content: Doo_StableLab:  During UST crash, we saw as you mentioned sentiment turn negative and a large portion of Dai converted back to USDC via PSM. But fundamentally, as Dai itself is over collateralized, it didn’t suffer as badly as others. In other words, it was not our understanding or lack of understanding of sentiment that helped us, it was the structure of the Dai peg.   Sure, DAI is overcollateralized. But how does it actually work? How is Collateralization Ratio determined? Surplus buffer? If all Maker needed was overcollateralization, if overcollateralization solved all problems, why would we need risk modelling? It’s important, because if collateral price drops fast enough + other factors like slippage => Maker is unable to recover full vault’s outstanding DAI => bad debt is accrued. In the worst case scenario this may lead to Maker becoming insolvent. Hence, price drop (aka market risk) scenarios must be predicted (simulated) to determine optimal parameter values. Problem is at the moment Risk CU is only able to cover about half (maybe less) of price movement risks, aka market risk. They couldn’t even if they wanted because they don’t have tools. In a nutshell. Risk CU runs a Collateral Risk Model trying to predict collateral price shocks’ effect on protocol economics. Its output determines a bunch of risk-driven vault parameters like Risk Premium and Debt Ceiling. Current design of the Model assumes market to be efficient and simulates price movements as a random process. That’s the definition of the Efficient-market hypothesis.  Image (7)1886×1069 194 KB  However, it was shown that only about 7% of the variance of annual stock market returns can be justified in terms of efficient market factors for the aggregate U.S. stock market 1871–1987. For individual-firm stock price variations it was estimated the standard deviation of the ‘‘atypical discount’’ was about 25%. It was concluded that the inefficient component of stock price variation that generates predictable movements in future returns ‘‘still has an economically significant impact on firm-level stock prices’. Importantly, given high correlation between crypto assets and due to the impact of sentiment/narrative on the crypto market through social media/social networks like Twitter and Discord, it’s very likely that the impact of inefficient market factors on crypto asset price movements is far higher than that for individual firm stock prices and closer to 50%, maybe more. See crypto bubbles/winters. This SPF is an effort towards covering the other (inefficient) half of market risks, which have an impact on collateral price variations => determine whether Maker is solvent at the end of the day. Moreover, The Federal Reserve Bank of New York has been gauging public sentiment since 2013 and integrating this data into its models. Baker and Wurgler reviewed the investor sentiment literature and showed that a “sentiment index” is highly correlated with aggregate stock returns. See also Handbook of Economic Expectations and an overview of literature on Expectations data in asset pricing in particular. See also Shiller’s book on Narrative economics. Bear market, the time when downward price shocks happen threatening protocol solvency, is exactly when such tooling is badly needed. You can’t just ignore inefficient market risks and hope they won’t materialise. @Matt_NZ

How would you propose the output of this model be integrated into the protocol? To me, it seems like the only time this model could be useful is if it could predict black swan type events (in which case the protocol would respond in anticipation by increasing rates & liquidation penalties, or something along those lines), which is extremely unlikely. Outside of black swan events, prediction of price doesn’t really matter at all, as liquidation penalties will very easily cover any slippage incurred in liquidation.

content.content: I worked on various NLP topics (question answering, topic modeling, etc.) before joining Maker and experienced first-hand just how difficult it is to programmatically encapsulate sentiment across social media sources (eg. how do you recognize sarcasm). Then there’s a layer of complexity to quantify it well and of course to integrate it into the existing modeling framework. The latter is a unique challenge as the model is not accommodated for this kind of input (which is crucial and lacking in your proposal). Leveraging modern language models such as FinBERT with additional tuning on crypto corpus definitely helps but that’s a relatively small part of the final solution that adds value. I wouldn’t put too much trust in behavioral economics literature (regardless of Nobel Prizes received) given that it’s a subset of behavioral science which has a massive replication crisis (37% of the research results can be replicated). Also, behavioral economic interventions have (on average) a 1.4% impact on outcome variables in the real world. Needless to say, the field as a whole mostly over-promises and under-delivers empirically. To move beyond theory, in our Collateral Risk Model there is no EMH assumption. As @lyt mentioned, we don’t try to predict price movement (Black Swans), we rather focus on what we see as knowable. For all the unknowable aspects of the Maker system (there’s many) we try to minimize related assumptions in the modeling process. We also don’t use any random processes for price movement that you mentioned as a proof for EMH assumption. We look at historical patterns for price shocks and add an additional layer of conservative assumptions. The key aspect of the model related to EMH is that we don’t divide market risk between efficient and inefficient movement (nor focus on either of them explicitly). We estimate a certain price shock, how the Maker system would respond and the consequences on protocol economics (as explained in the post that you shared).

content.content: UPDATE: In the last several days I’ve been in contact with Jan of Risk CU. My initial premise was based on Risk CU’s presentation outlining Risk Model design. In particular it states that the input about asset prices was modeled with GBM – Geometric Brownian Motion. GBM is a standard model of a random process. Hence, the assumption is that collateral price movement is random => Efficient Market Hypothesis assumption.      The GBM methodology has been deprecated, because it required inclusion of estimates about non-EHM volatility => it doesn’t allow to adequately assess risks of price shocks. Now the approach is to assess collateral price volatility risks based on historical extremums. This leads to extremely conservative protocol parameter values => reduced capital efficiency. I’m reworking my proposal to highlight that integrating the crypto community sentiment component into the Risk Model will  bring risk assessments to the more realistic middle ground between underestimating risks (random process + arbitrary volatility multiplier) and conservative policy based on the worst case scenarios ever happened on the market. This will improve capital efficiency, which will bring value both for the DAO and to the Maker users.

content.content: To illustrate yet another time the importance of sentiment dynamics analysis of financial markets: a quote  from today’s Nobel Prize in economics 2022 explanation:  In their theory, Diamond and Dybvig show how banks offer an optimal solution to this problem. By acting as intermediaries that accept deposits from many savers, banks can allow depositors to access their money when they wish, while also offering long-term loans to borrowers. However, their analysis also showed how the combination of these two activities makes banks vulnerable to rumours about their imminent collapse. If a large number of savers simultaneously run to the bank to withdraw their money, the rumour may become a self-fulfilling prophecy – a bank run occurs and the bank collapses.
